cyclone.name: IRMA
cyclone.current_location: eye passing over Barbuda in the northern Leeward Islands
cyclone.trajectory: moving west-northwest across the northern Leeward Islands, forecast to skirt the northern Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico, then curve toward the Bahamas/Cuba Strait and the Florida Peninsula
cyclone.expected_landfall_location: South or south-central Florida (Keys or extreme south-west coast)

weather_observation.impacted_coast: Northern Cuba, Bahamas, Florida Peninsula and Keys, eventually the eastern Gulf coast including Tampa Bay
weather_observation.storm_surge_above_3_feet: Likely if the current track toward the west coast of Florida verifies
weather_observation.wind: Tropical-storm-force winds are a 33% chance within 5 days; 12% chance of 50-kt winds. Peak probabilities occur in roughly 4–5 days (Sun–Mon).
weather_observation.storm_surge: If Irma moves north along or just inland of the west-central Florida coast, onshore flow in Tampa Bay could drive water levels above 3 ft, potentially much higher with a major hurricane.
weather_observation.rainfall: Heavy rain bands associated with Irma could deliver more than 4 inches of rain to the Tampa Bay area early next week, causing flash-flood concerns.
weather_observation.other_hazards: Very rough seas in the approaches to Tampa Bay, dangerous rip currents, and potential port access channel shoaling.
